commit_message:
Add DCN Scale Out Roles

In Id6c416b8c7b3b6314d935e3eeb8a3f114492cecd the roles for
DistributedCompute and DistributedComputeHCI received the
GlanceApiEdge service so that Glance could run at DCN sites.
Those who wish to run >3 DCN nodes with Glance may then add
scale out roles by replacing the GlanceApiEdge service with
the new HAproxyEdge service, which configures a local haproxy
to forward glance-api requests to edge nodes running Glance.
This patch provides the DistributedComputeScaleOut and
DistributedComputeHCIScaleOut roles so that deployers may
specify 3 DCN nodes and N DCN scale out nodes without having
to compose the roles themselves.

Change-Id: I8900ba3bb470804b5bb5016aacc66dc171e1bb62

subject: Archive logs before pulling them to localhost
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6683, 'name': 'Pavel Sedlák', 'email': 'psedlak@redhat.com', 'username': 'psedlak'}, {'_account_id': 8367, 'name': 'Arx Cruz', 'email': 'arxcruz@redhat.com', 'username': 'arxcruz'}, {'_account_id': 9592, 'name': 'wes hayutin', 'email': 'whayutin@redhat.com', 'username': 'weshayutin'}, {'_account_id': 10969, 'name': 'Shnaidman Sagi (Sergey)', 'display_name': 'Shnaidman Sagi', 'email': 'sshnaidm@redhat.com', 'username': 'sergsh'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22873, 'name': 'Martin Kopec', 'email': 'mkopec@redhat.com', 'username': 'mkopec'}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 24162, 'name': 'Sorin Sbârnea', 'display_name': 'zbr', 'email': 'ssbarnea@redhat.com', 'username': 'ssbarnea', 'status': 'do not feed the troll 🥕'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2020-02-05 00:12:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2020-02-05 08:13:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2020-02-05 15:41:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2020-02-06 11:46:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Please, do not change the behavior of artcl_gzip which is designed to archive only files above specific size.

If we are to move archival from localhost to the targeted hosts, we need to assure we run (reuse) the same code.

I have reasons to believe that edge compression may impose new issues: 

- what if targeted host run out of disk?
- you may not archive files that are being written, or cause services to fail

I am inclined to prefer being more of an observer on targeted hosts and keep most write operations to localhost (collector).

Still, I am aware that others may have different options so it could make sense to make this configurable.'}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2020-02-06 14:50:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Please, do not change the behavior of artcl_gzip which is designed
 > to archive only files above specific size.
 > 
 > If we are to move archival from localhost to the targeted hosts, we
 > need to assure we run (reuse) the same code.
 > 
 > I have reasons to believe that edge compression may impose new
 > issues:
 > 
 > - what if targeted host run out of disk?
 > - you may not archive files that are being written, or cause
 > services to fail
 > 
 > I am inclined to prefer being more of an observer on targeted hosts
 > and keep most write operations to localhost (collector).
 > 
 > Still, I am aware that others may have different options so it
 > could make sense to make this configurable.

ok, I see, I understand and it totally makes sense, although based on my experiments, rsyncing logs without any compression from target host (openstack node) to the collector (localhost) was extremely slow, more than 100% slow - that's tens of minutes .. let me rerun a few jobs to make sure ...

how often does happen a situation that a node ran out of disk? 

I can move this logic under a new parameter, that would work too but I still think moving logs without compression is not the best idea. I'm gonna look for some alternative methods which would require less free disk space, if there are any."}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2020-02-06 15:10:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

btw, do we have to first collect all logs to /tmp on the node we're collecting logs and then syncing them to localhost (collector)? what if we did direct rsync to localhost? speaking about that, Attila mentioned ssh+tar method, so IIUC, we could:
1. (in case of artifact server doesn't need to receive compressed files) transfer logs directly to collector (we would omit the current task: Gather the logs to /tmp)and then publish 
2. (in case artifact server can receive compressed files) transfer logs directly to collector using ssh+tar method and then publish

what do you think?"}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2020-02-06 15:12:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Usually the builder should be in the same geo location as the nodes used by it. If not it an infra issue.

Rsync does also transport compression which can help a lot on long distance calls with a bit of extra cpu load, but is totally tranparent. I no longer remember if we have that enabled by default or not but it would make sense to double check it. 

If you enable it, do not change the compression level, default one is well picked to avoid wasting too much cpu.'}, {'account_id': 6683, 'date': '2020-02-07 10:06:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

This is not about how infra is structured.

Copying files over without proper compression and compressing them then, all at once node, is just very inefficient:
- network bandwitdh (we are talking diff of few 10s of MBs vs GBs of data so even on fast networks its way faster)
- if compression is to be done anyway, theoretically it's time (like spent on original node) can be ignored as being same (although next point)
- compression is distributed across all involved nodes, not done slower at end on single node (re distributing hw load, not talking about them being compressed in parallel or serial at the end)

In case collected files are to be compressed (as per role user request), there is no reason to not compress them at first chance.
And then just move/manipulate the final ones.

Also please notice, that this is not aimed only on CI, but command line users of infrared too, and I would have doubts if they can afford moving their laptops to different datacenters each time they use it.
As such, all-together, and as soon as possible compression is current requirement for infrared compatibility, mainly to not end up with two times slower log collection.


- Re running out of disk: if that is expected issue then files cannot be copied even locally (e.g. to /tmp, or even localhost if that is single like standalone env), and need to be send through tar+compression pipe over network. And here we are talking again e.g. 1.5GB of local copying vs 50MB extra for compressed archive.

- If reading files which are written to by services causes their failure it's clearly their bug and should be fixed, but not seen such case for ... even cannot remember if ever. But would be same issue with cp/rsync woudln't it? Archiving files which are appended to also not expected to be real problem, we are ok grabbing whatever content is there at the time we collect it, also same as copying would do.

In case You do not want things compressed (like as requested by artcl_gzip:false, or something like artcl_tar:false [see inline]), obviously then it should not compress when collecting (except that rsync --compress, but that is very different compression then compressing one tar file together, and should have no effect on output)."}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2020-02-07 11:22:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2020-02-07 16:38:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

(1 comment)

https://docs.openstack.org/infra/system-config/third_party.html

logs must be browsable; logs requiring download, installation or login to access are not acceptable'}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2020-02-08 09:36:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

logs must be browsable; logs requiring download, installation or login to access are not acceptable => yes, but only in case they are uploaded to upstream artifact servers. However, this collect logs might be used elsewhere:
- f.e. for downloading logs to user's localhost for only debugging purpose without any intention to upload it anywhere
- f.e. for collecting logs in downstream infrastructures where, maybe it's a big surprise, might be different artifact servers which don't have those requirement on log format

it's all about reusability, if there is no tar, the role just simply can't be reused in some cases. For example, my experiment jenkins jobs I've been using collect-logs there collect approx 18 - 22 thousands files of 600MB - 1GB of size. In a compressed format their size is about 60MB-85MB - tenth of original size. When I tried to sync those files in an uncompressed format, it took forever to collect, download to localhost and the publish part took even more time - the role timeouted (so publish part took more than 15 minutes) - the whole collect plus partial publish part took about 50 minutes all together, which is way beyond acceptable.

Moreover, copying huge amount of files over internet in an uncompressed format it's just bullshit. I'm speaking only about the part where the logs are moved from nodes to localhost (executor), no publishing yet.

Let's say that the logs are magically downloaded to localhost (executor) in whatever way (efficient or the slowest possible one) and they are about to be published. There is more use cases where the logs might be published except the upstream one. 
Users may:
- want to publish them to upstream openstack servers (great, in that case the logs will be published in an uncompressed format as it is now - we may want to add a BIG NOTE above artcl_tar_gz option with a warning that its usage is not compatible with the upstream servers)
- not want to publish them anywhere as already mentioned
- want to publish them to some private servers where they have maybe additional logic which will handle the logs, uncompress them or not, who knows, it's a private server and it's totally up to user.

I added the artcl_tar_gz option which is set by default to False, so I didn't change the current behavior. I think adding another option to provide users a slightly different way of handling the logs which even widen cases where the role might be used is absolutely normal. Well, unless there is no intention to make other than usptream users to use it."}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2020-02-08 10:31:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I think that once we manage to make collection commands extensible, you will be able to perform compression (or any other tasks) before rsync begins. This means same special need could be fulfilled without introducing additional complexity to the role.

Take a look at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/705623/ which is the firs step towards allowing you to inject extra commands. if you made a tar.gz out of all logs in a custom command, that is what you will get rsynced.

Wes pointed to a very important document related to OpenStack standards, ones that are supposed to be followed by everyone, not only upstream. Maybe it would make bit of sense to rethink that tar.gz approach as it seems more like an infra issue than code issue. What if tomorrow someones argues that it takes too long to copy files over a 2400bps modem and he cannot afford to store more than 1.44MB per build so they fit a floppy disk. (/end-joke)

I do still want to assure that this role is reusable by any openstack deployments, but avoiding scope-creeping. Let's see how we can achieve the same effects without adding unnecessary complexity to the code.

Any conditional branch we add to it works against that, but if we can do it without conditions, it should be fine."}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2020-02-08 12:07:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> I think that once we manage to make collection commands extensible,
 > you will be able to perform compression (or any other tasks) before
 > rsync begins. This means same special need could be fulfilled
 > without introducing additional complexity to the role.
It might work, the question is when and if it is better than archiving all logs at once.
 
 > Take a look at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/705623/ which is the
 > firs step towards allowing you to inject extra commands. if you
 > made a tar.gz out of all logs in a custom command, that is what you
 > will get rsynced.
The change looks good, it's a quite clean way how to run all the commands inside one task. Maybe one more variable is needed to allow users adding some custom commands on top of those in artcl_commands.

 > Wes pointed to a very important document related to OpenStack
 > standards, ones that are supposed to be followed by everyone, not
 > only upstream.
I think it's important to highlight who's included in "everyone" - as the title of the page states, the standards are for third party testing. That said, it's for users/jobs that vote in gerrit. Of course this must be a standard in order to have all the logs published by third party jobs organized the same way (in other words, standardized) and I'm not arguing with that. 
What I'm saying is that not every job is a third party job and voting in gerrit. 
Also the doc is speaking about standards for published logs. This role can be (and should be at some point) divided into two parts - collecting and publishing. This proposed change affects mainly collecting part. The collected logs can be uncompressed on localhost before they are published in order to comply with the standards.

 > Maybe it would make bit of sense to rethink that
 > tar.gz approach as it seems more like an infra issue than code
 > issue. What if tomorrow someones argues that it takes too long to
 > copy files over a 2400bps modem and he cannot afford to store more
 > than 1.44MB per build so they fit a floppy disk. (/end-joke)
yeah, let's blame someone else and find excuses, that will solve all the problems. A code should be always written as efficient as possible. I agree that infrastructures are better every year and we don't have deal with problems like 20 years ago (not enought memory, weak cpus ..) but that doesn't mean we should waste resources just because we can.

 > I do still want to assure that this role is reusable by any
 > openstack deployments, but avoiding scope-creeping. Let's see how
 > we can achieve the same effects without adding unnecessary
 > complexity to the code.
It won't be scope-creeping if we finally agree on what the third party standardization means and what part of collect-logs is touched by that. 

 > Any conditional branch we add to it works against that, but if we
 > can do it without conditions, it should be fine.
Conditions are not bad, if they are reasonable. For example tasks/publish.yml contains three conditions regarding uploading logs (for uploading to a swift server, to a server using public key or using password authentication. And this very similar, the user would have an option to either compressed the logs or not depending on user's needs.'}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2020-02-14 13:17:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-02-16 09:28:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

let's go from https://review.opendev.org/#/c/706797/"}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2020-02-17 22:54:23.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This one will do the trick: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/706797/'}]

commit_message:
Archive logs before pulling them to localhost

Archive logs, when artcl_tar_gz is set to True, on a remote node
before they are rsynced to the executor node. Copying just one
file instead of many makes the synchronization dramatically
more efficient in case of larger amount of files.

Change-Id: I1b203277f5246cabe732701a6996a5441334a3b0

When using pre-deployed nodes installed with minimal OS, it may happen

commit_message:
Ensures rsync is present on the overcloud nodes

When using pre-deployed nodes installed with minimal OS, it may happen
rsync is missing - this package is needed for the "Sync cached facts"
task for instance.

Change-Id: Ie8a1ad5e2c9e32cce1f1b8c264a8b44207d99b59
Closes-Bug: #1863216
Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1802827

Change-Id: Ibd56e93ad7f398b04ec7fb9281af5d42d0e1548f

commit_message:
Cleanup and improve testing

Small improvements to testing, some cleanup
in formatting and changing the default value
for the password parameter by making it required
and removing the undef default value (instead
of using fail).

Change-Id: Ibd56e93ad7f398b04ec7fb9281af5d42d0e1548f

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-17 19:00:35.000000000', 'message': 'Fix a ValueError with mock 4.0.1

Mock version 4.0.1 raises a ValueError with the current mock "spec"
for the secrets.Secret[1]. This patch resolves this issue by running
"dir(secrets.Secret)" for mock. This is what mock should be doing
automatically, but this object appears to be confusing it.

[1] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/ \
    c5fd6cadc9bf4b3b9ea81372ef047246/log/job-output.txt#4605

Change-Id: I6794144b2ba66f3bbd2bc948d95d1019286c9889
'}]
commit_message:
Fix a ValueError with mock 4.0.1

Mock version 4.0.1 raises a ValueError with the current mock "spec"
for the secrets.Secret[1]. This patch resolves this issue by running
"dir(secrets.Secret)" for mock. This is what mock should be doing
automatically, but this object appears to be confusing it.

[1] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/ \
    c5fd6cadc9bf4b3b9ea81372ef047246/log/job-output.txt#4605

Change-Id: I6794144b2ba66f3bbd2bc948d95d1019286c9889

commit_message:
tripleo_container_manage: avoid excessive logging with podman facts

podman_container_info module generates a bunch of logging, which is all
infos reported by podman inspect. It's useful only when you do some
debug; so let's disable its output when debug isn't enabled.

Change-Id: Ib35d18e5bfa8bbfdff75fda6c52ea7c770f6f986

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-13 19:09:39.000000000', 'message': "tripleo_container_manage: reduce downtime for minor updates

If a container has a new config (e.g. new image), it'll now be removed
right before being re-created.

Before, we were first removing that container among potential orphan
containers, and the container would be re-created later but the downtime
in the middle can be several minutes; since we batch the container
creation.

Now, we separate the cleanup of orphan containers and the ones with new
configs.

The workflow is the following:

1) Remove orphan containers (not in the config anymore, missing Labels,
   etc).

Then for each batch of containers:

2) Remove the containers where the config_data has changed.

3) Create the containers that are in the config.

This patch should reduce the downtime of containers that are updated.

Change-Id: I821d674dead4a21b7ac30b47b31b8dd34e0ecc8b

commit_message:
tripleo_container_manage: reduce downtime for minor updates

If a container has a new config (e.g. new image), it'll now be removed
right before being re-created.

Before, we were first removing that container among potential orphan
containers, and the container would be re-created later but the downtime
in the middle can be several minutes; since we batch the container
creation.

Now, we separate the cleanup of orphan containers and the ones with new
configs.

The workflow is the following:

1) Remove orphan containers (not in the config anymore, missing Labels,
   etc).

Then for each batch of containers:

2) Remove the containers where the config_data has changed.

3) Create the containers that are in the config.

This patch should reduce the downtime of containers that are updated.

Change-Id: I821d674dead4a21b7ac30b47b31b8dd34e0ecc8b

commit_message:
Add 'fip-port-details' to OVN ML2 supported extensions

This extension will add information about the attached port in the
floating IP dictionary.

This extension is not mandatory but very handy because sometime this
extra information avoids to make a second call to Neutron.

Related-Bug: #1861876

Change-Id: I0175a2d00256e6d904cbcf25ad4a08aa825a9e18

start, in the VLAN driver initialization.

commit_message:
Reduce the VLAN/tunneled ranges in fullstack tests

Reduce the number of VLAN and tunneled network ranges (GRE, VXLAN)
to 30 tags, in fullstack tests. This will reduce the amount of time
spent, during the Neutron server start, in the VLAN and tunnel
drivers initialization.

Partial-Bug: #1862178

Change-Id: I7ae82d163c46bbc3ee7430293555c66fbda17b08

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-11 20:25:00.000000000', 'message': "tripleo-container-manage: introduce tripleo_container_manage_cleanup

Introduce tripleo_container_manage_cleanup parameter for the
tripleo-container-manage role.

Context:
In Paunch, a container that would be present on the host, managed by
Paunch, with the config_id given in parameter, but not present in the
JSON config for that step; would be removed. The use case is when
containers aren't needed anymore between releases, they are removed.

To match this, we add the condition into the needs_delete() filter; but
also let the operator the ability to disable it with
tripleo_container_manage_cleanup parameter.

If tripleo_container_manage_cleanup parameter is set to False, a
container that is on the host with tripleo_step1 but not anymore in a
given config for tripleo_step1 wouldn't be removed.

Opposite applies if tripleo_container_manage_cleanup is set to True.

Change-Id: Ic06ac0f41767ca513c612b1ebb38d2ff92500ea5
"}, {'created': '2020-02-11 20:26:35.000000000', 'message': "tripleo-container-manage: introduce tripleo_container_manage_cleanup

Introduce tripleo_container_manage_cleanup parameter for the
tripleo-container-manage role.

Context:
In Paunch, a container that would be present on the host, managed by
Paunch, with the config_id given in parameter, but not present in the
JSON config for that step; would be removed. The use case is when
containers aren't needed anymore between releases, they are removed.

To match this, we add the condition into the needs_delete() filter; but
also let the operator the ability to disable it with
tripleo_container_manage_cleanup parameter.

If tripleo_container_manage_cleanup parameter is set to False, a
container that is on the host with tripleo_step1 but not anymore in a
given config for tripleo_step1 wouldn't be removed.

Opposite applies if tripleo_container_manage_cleanup is set to True.

Note: that commit also adds 'continue' each time we figure out what to
do with that container (whether skipping or deleting it).

Change-Id: Ic06ac0f41767ca513c612b1ebb38d2ff92500ea5

"}, {'created': '2020-02-16 16:28:34.000000000', 'message': "tripleo_container_manage: reduce cleanup when single config is given

If a single JSON file is given to tripleo_container_manage_config, we
don't want to remove containers from the same config in that directory,
we just want to manage that container. Which is often used to either
debug or just controlling one container at a time (FFU).

This patch will change the needs_delete() filter, and if only one config
is given, we won't cleanup other containers.

Change-Id: Ic06ac0f41767ca513c612b1ebb38d2ff92500ea5

commit_message:
tripleo_container_manage: reduce cleanup when single config is given

If a single JSON file is given to tripleo_container_manage_config, we
don't want to remove containers from the same config in that directory,
we just want to manage that container. Which is often used to either
debug or just controlling one container at a time (FFU).

This patch will change the needs_delete() filter, and if only one config
is given, we won't cleanup other containers.

We also add the clean_orphans config param to the method, so we can
override it later.

Also if no config is given (could be due to a wrong given
tripleo_container_manage_config_patterns which would not match
anything), we don't want to remove anything for safety purpose.

Change-Id: Ic06ac0f41767ca513c612b1ebb38d2ff92500ea5

are never interpreted or changed during ingestion or transit.

As a preventative measure we should always use it rather than

commit_message:
Switch from using cat to slurp

Slurp is binary safe, ensuring that all contents of the file
are never interpreted or changed during ingestion or transit.

As a preventative measure we should always use it rather than
assume that using cat will result in safe content transit.

Note that tasks/common/adjust-roles-data.yaml is left as-is
due to the change to use slurp already being included in
Iecf2b0211a69e99efe0f402efb00c7080b784104

Change-Id: Ib8309dca36ac804ec17761f6301b1b220411afff

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-04 18:30:23.000000000', 'message': 'Remove mistral from the config_download deploy workflow

This change removes all of mistral from the config_download_deploy function
by calling the required functions directly.

- All of the inputs within this function have been cleaned up and documented.
- New log entires will be created when using this method giving the deployer
  a better overall user experience.

With the new streamlined execution process we should see improved deployment
times and better visability into the deployment process.

"}, {'created': '2020-02-11 03:09:13.000000000', 'message': "Remove mistral from the config_download deploy workflow

This change removes all of mistral from the config_download_deploy function
by calling the required functions directly.

- All of the inputs within this function have been cleaned up and documented.
- New log entires will be created when using this method giving the deployer
  a better overall user experience.
- To ensure we're able to support the ability to reproduce commands, the ssh
  args extravar has been moved to an environment variable.
- The methods get_config and get_key have been moved to the utils module.
  This was done to help avoid circular imports.
- Update commands have all been updated to use the new config_download method.
  This was done in this commit because supporting both mistral based and
  non-mistral config_download processes was not practical.

With the new streamlined execution process we should see improved deployment
times and better visability into the deployment process.

"}, {'created': '2020-02-13 22:25:33.000000000', 'message': "Remove mistral from the config_download deploy workflow

This change removes all of mistral from the config_download_deploy function
by calling the required functions directly.

- All of the inputs within this function have been cleaned up and documented.
- New log entires will be created when using this method giving the deployer
  a better overall user experience.
- To ensure we're able to support the ability to reproduce commands, the ssh
  args extravar has been moved to an environment variable.
- The methods get_config and get_key have been moved to the utils module.
  This was done to help avoid circular imports.

Update methods have been changed to execute without running within a mistral
workflow. This was changed because there's no need to support the multiple
code paths anymore given config_download is now running directly.

Test classes have been updated to reduce duplication.

With the new streamlined execution process we should see improved deployment
times and better visability into the deployment process.

commit_message:
Remove mistral from the config_download deploy workflow

This change removes all of mistral from the config_download_deploy function
by calling the required functions directly.

- All of the inputs within this function have been cleaned up and documented.
- New log entires will be created when using this method giving the deployer
  a better overall user experience.
- To ensure we're able to support the ability to reproduce commands, the ssh
  args extravar has been moved to an environment variable.
- The methods get_config and get_key have been moved to the utils module.
  This was done to help avoid circular imports.

Update methods have been changed to execute without running within a mistral
workflow. This was changed because there's no need to support the multiple
code paths anymore given config_download is now running directly.

Test classes have been updated to reduce duplication.

With the new streamlined execution process we should see improved deployment
times and better visability into the deployment process.

Task: 38422
Story: 2007212

Depends-On: I006291a2465aa4c950abce76f9e5f9459b76e330
Change-Id: Ide1a4503dd2bdd2d5e494cd1eac483b842a21acf
Co-authored-by: Luke Short <ekultails@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Dougal Matthews <dougal@dougalmatthews.com>
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
tripleo_container_manage: create a filter to get changed containers

Getting to know which containers changed is a challenge since we create
the containers in async with podman_container.

This patch introduces a new filter, called get_changed_containers() which
knows how to use returned data from async and figure out what containers
have podman actions (which mean podman rm and create); which have to
trigger the systemd playbook and make sure the services are triggering
changes in systemd.

Change-Id: I2ecf7d942dcca1e381d329e11939fd31299551f5

[{'created': '2020-02-07 13:16:21.000000000', 'message': 'Octavia: do not attempt container restart on empty list

With composable roles, the node with the octavia agents may not have any
processes running when we hit step 5 external deploy tasks, resulting in
our "one line" restart failing. This patch splits the query for octavia
containers out into a separate task and we conditionally run the restart
task depending on whether there are containers found.

Change-Id: I08a06b300d43aca7db2c9e3341a07bc903163d26

(cherry picked from commit 1bafe4df85cb34990f4ed2f85dbb094f9c96762b)

commit_message:
Octavia: do not attempt container restart on empty list

With composable roles, the node with the octavia agents may not have any
processes running when we hit step 5 external deploy tasks, resulting in
our "one line" restart failing. This patch splits the query for octavia
containers out into a separate task and we conditionally run the restart
task depending on whether there are containers found.

Change-Id: I08a06b300d43aca7db2c9e3341a07bc903163d26
Closes-Bug: #1861413
(cherry picked from commit 1bafe4df85cb34990f4ed2f85dbb094f9c96762b)

When purging the docker service/directories, if there has
been an operating system upgrade in between (RHEL7 to

commit_message:
Stop docker service when is available only.

When purging the docker service/directories, if there has
been an operating system upgrade in between (RHEL7 to
RHEL8), then the docker service will be inactive but the
folders used by Docker still need a purge. If the service
is not available and we try to stop it, then the Ansible
service task will fail.

This patch adds a guard to stop the service only when it
is available in the system.

Change-Id: Id6dc9a7bd71a7725ae1672c91bef5064a730b530
(cherry picked from commit dd55c86e1d32963da4d3edea6c137b4444e0477a)

commit_message:
Allow to update container startup config with new config hashes

1) container_puppet_config: introduce update_config_hash_only

If update_config_hash_only is set to True, the module will do the
following:

Browse the container startup configs and for each config, check if the
config_hash has changed (e.g. Puppet has run before and generated a new
config, therefore the container will need a restart); then update the
startup configs with the new hash.

This extends container_puppet_config capabilities instead of writting a
new module for that.

2) tripleo_container_manage: add tripleo_container_manage_check_puppet_config

tripleo_container_manage_check_puppet_config is a new parameter, that is
set to False by default but if set to True, we will call the
container_puppet_config module with update_config_hash_only set to True
so we get the new config hashes in the container startup configs right
before we decide if a container needs to be restarted.

Change-Id: I16b2972cdf79cd6ac927925607197ec2a969a28b

commit_message:
WIP: parameterize amphora download path

The Octavia deployment has version dependent requirements and
restrictions on where the amphora image can be accessed. e.g. Not the
deployer's home directory in queens and rocky.

Change-Id: I9f1166a7126049e2d358aa7a17f48da868d346f8

commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - Get Manageable Volumes Fix

Fix for getting a list of manageable volumes.
In Unisphere 91 and beyond, the nameModifier
key is no longer available in volume headers.
Change references to userDefinedIdentifier.

commit_message:
[update] Ensure we get fresh hiera data before running update_steps.

We need to make sure that the hiera data are fresh before the update
step so that anyone using those data during those steps are seeing the
latest information from heat.

Factor out the hiera generation and include it in deployment and
update playbooks.

The double tasks definition in the deployment playbook seemed to be
redundant so It has been removed.

Change-Id: I6b6c676880ccc8cbed23af135e5865c222a8f1d0
Closes-Bug: #1861799
With some adjustment:
(cherry picked from commit 536230b323e5c3ac41e6ed990360317cdb5bc702)

commit_message:
Install versioned python RPMs on RedHat distros

Set default python3 version as 3 for cases python3
is not installed before running DevStack.

Implements installation of required python3x package
for RedHat family distros with package name depending on
configurable ${PYTHON3_VERSION}. Examples:

  3 => python3 python3-devel (default one)
  3.6 => python36 python36-devel
  3.7 => python37 python37-devel

This should help in situations where there are more
than one python available for given platform and
DevStack is asked to pick one by its full 3.x version

Change-Id: I49d86bc9193165e0a41e8e8720be37d81a4e7ee0

commit_message:
container_puppet_config: update config_hash for all steps

Every time the container_puppet_config module will be called, we will go
over all container startup config and update the config hash if the
config volume was changed.

It'll make sure that configs are always up to date; so we avoid useless
container restarts after an initial deployment.

Also improve the logging to show the container name when config hash
changed, instead of this whole path.

Change-Id: I67ec7ad661c0649a3448437397c0de55be984589

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-13 21:05:08.000000000', 'message': "container_puppet_config: cleanup old config files

In I98963941c9d969ab1dfd92d70f973013f84e1c25, we removed
/var/lib/docker-puppet and
/var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config-*.json.
Also, since the usage of container_puppet_config, there is no more
'hashed-' file when a container has a new config hash. The hash is
included in the same container config file.

The container_puppet_config module will take care of making sure no old
container startup config remains in /var/lib/tripleo-config as well as
hashed files; which aren't useful anymore and could cause troubles and
confusion.

This patch will have to be backported to stable/train.

Change-Id: I595a998196b6de386a4ff345c39fe1e6a9ed62c6
(cherry picked from commit 57dfadc1f4bd5dcbefeb24892c7e28fef65d1e58)
"}]
commit_message:
container_puppet_config: cleanup old config files

In I98963941c9d969ab1dfd92d70f973013f84e1c25, we removed
/var/lib/docker-puppet and
/var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config-*.json.
Also, since the usage of container_puppet_config, there is no more
'hashed-' file when a container has a new config hash. The hash is
included in the same container config file.

The container_puppet_config module will take care of making sure no old
container startup config remains in /var/lib/tripleo-config as well as
hashed files; which aren't useful anymore and could cause troubles and
confusion.

This patch will have to be backported to stable/train.

Change-Id: I595a998196b6de386a4ff345c39fe1e6a9ed62c6
(cherry picked from commit 57dfadc1f4bd5dcbefeb24892c7e28fef65d1e58)
